text: Attachment principles teach us that most people are only as needy as their unmet needs. When their emotional needs are met, and the earlier the better, they usually turn their attention outward. This is sometimes referred to in attachment literature as the “dependency paradox”: The more effectively dependent people are on one another, the more independent and daring they become.
title: Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment and How It Can Help You Findâand KeepâLove
author: Amir Levine, Rachel Heller

text: This is an important lesson for someone with an anxious attachment style: If you just wait a little longer before reacting and jumping to conclusions, you will have an uncanny ability to decipher the world around you and use it to your advantage. But shoot from the hip, and you’re all over the place making misjudgments and hurting yourself.
title: Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment and How It Can Help You Findâand KeepâLove
author: Amir Levine, Rachel Heller

text: When our partner is unable to meet our basic attachment needs, we experience a chronic sense of disquiet and tension that leaves us more exposed to various ailments. Not only is our emotional well-being sacrificed when we are in a romantic partnership with someone who doesn’t provide a secure base, but so is our physical health.
title: Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment and How It Can Help You Findâand KeepâLove
author: Amir Levine, Rachel Heller

text: Activating strategies are any thoughts or feelings that compel you to get close, physically or emotionally, to your partner. Once he or she responds to you in a way that reestablishes security, you can revert back to your calm, normal self.
title: Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment and How It Can Help You Findâand KeepâLove
author: Amir Levine, Rachel Heller

text: A deactivating strategy is any behavior or thought that is used to squelch intimacy. These strategies suppress our attachment system, the biological mechanism in our brains responsible for our desire to seek closeness with a preferred partner.
title: Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment and How It Can Help You Findâand KeepâLove
author: Amir Levine, Rachel Heller

text: Other studies have found that faced with a stressful life event, such as divorce, the birth of a severely disabled child, or military trauma, avoidants’ defenses are quick to break down and they then appear and behave just like people with an anxious attachment style.
title: Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment and How It Can Help You Findâand KeepâLove
author: Amir Levine, Rachel Heller

text: Getting attached means that our brain becomes wired to seek the support of our partner by ensuring their psychological and physical proximity. If our partner fails to reassure us, we are programmed to continue our attempts to achieve closeness until they do.
title: Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment and How It Can Help You Findâand KeepâLove
author: Amir Levine, Rachel Heller

text: Numerous studies show that once we become attached to someone, the two of us form one physiological unit. Our partner regulates our blood pressure, our heart rate, our breathing, and the levels of hormones in our blood. We are no longer separate entities. The emphasis on differentiation that is held by most of today’s popular psychology approaches to adult relationships does not hold water from a biological perspective. Dependency is a fact; it is not a choice or a preference.
title: Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment and How It Can Help You Findâand KeepâLove
author: Amir Levine, Rachel Heller

text: If you want to take the road to independence and happiness, first find the right person to depend on and travel down it with them.
title: Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment and How It Can Help You Findâand KeepâLove
author: Amir Levine, Rachel Heller

text: Getting attached means that our brain becomes wired to seek the support of our partner by ensuring the partner’s psychological and physical proximity. If our partner fails to reassure us, we are programmed to continue our attempts to achieve closeness until the partner does.
title: Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment and How It Can Help You Findâand KeepâLove

title: Project Hail Mary
author: Andy Weir;

text: “Hello!” Ilyukhina lunged forward and hugged Stratt. “I’m here to die for Earth! Pretty awesome, yes?!”
title: Project Hail Mary
author: Andy Weir;

text: Stupid humanity. Getting in the way of my hobbies.
title: Project Hail Mary
author: Andy Weir;

text: He’s a monostome—that is, the waste comes out the same opening that food goes into.
title: Project Hail Mary
author: Andy Weir;

text: You are stupid right now. You sleep.
title: Project Hail Mary
author: Andy Weir;

text:
I am sorry for it all. Sorrow
grows in me like cattails choking
a pond. Sorrow, regret, remorse.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
Maybe they already knew
when you have a child you sign up
for a love that can carve
a canyon in your heart.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
After we weep, we fold the newspaper
and drive our kids to school.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
How does the love keep
swelling in the cavities of our frail bodies,
how do these husks hold so much jagged
pleasure in their parched split skins?
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
So I am alone
with my epiphany and the moon,
that I have come, just now, to realize is truly out there—
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
I have worried
all over the world. It comes to me easily.
Formed slowly through childhood
like stalactites in a cave.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
of crushed mint, Chopin’s Nocturnes,
your child’s birth, a kiss,
or even me—in my chilly kitchen
with my coat over my nightgown—thinking of you.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
In a poem, we don’t care if you got hired
or fired, lost or found love,
recovered or kept drinking.
You don’t have to exercise
or forgive. We’re hungry.
We’ll take everything on the menu.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
He’d never believed in them. She, though, scooped
them up like water, let them drip through her fingers
like someone who has so much she can afford to waste.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
His daughter dead
of brain cancer, and his wife following like earth
into that grave.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
Soon you’ll place bookmarks and
go upstairs. I’ve seen your room
with its sloping ceiling. Your bed.
I won’t imagine more.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
there are mornings when I wake, my lips
swollen from your kisses,
my body bruised and fragrant
as grasses on which lions have lain,
and for a full bereft moment, I cannot,
for the life of me, remember
why I left.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
Or driving back from Poipu Beach, the children slumped against you,
the moon flashing through the thousand palms.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
Bring me your pain, love. Spread
it out like fine rugs, silk sashes,
warm eggs, cinnamon
and cloves in burlap sacks.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
I would lift it
tenderly, as a great animal might
carry a small one in the private
cave of the mouth.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
I rearranged the turkey sandwiches
for the flight home
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
Should we tell him the truth?
That he’ll never get over her. Love
is a rock in the surf off the Pacific. Life
batters it. No matter how small it gets
it will always be there—grain of sand
chafing the heart.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
And when he’s dying—
even if I go to him—I’ll be little more
than a dumb bouquet, spilling my scent.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
A lone fisherman drifted by, casting his ribbon of light.
“Do you feel like you’ve given her away?” you asked.
But no, it was that she made it
to here, that she didn’t
drown in a well or die
of pneumonia or take the pills.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
I look down
at the knife, as if I were carrying it to the drawer
and took a wrong turn.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
I lean
into this stranger, seeking primitive comfort—
heat, touch, breath—as we slip
into the ancient vulnerability of sleep.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
Then a year goes by. Or two.
Like broken bones, they knit back together.
They grow like grass and bushes and trees
after a forest fire, covering the seared earth.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
I think there must be something more to say.
But she’s already told me she’s not afraid
to die. And the rest, even I know, is obvious.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
They worry about bills. They worry
whether the shoes they just bought
are really too small. One’s husband died,
her son left for college, and she doesn’t
know how to program the VCR.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text:
Those who can, cling to their mates,
an ear pressed to those neighboring lungs like a
stethoscope, hoping to catch a ride
on the steady sleep breath of the other, to be carried
like a seed on the body of the one who is able.
title: Mules of Love
author: Ellen Bass

text: She has never believed herself fit to be loved by any person. But now she has a new life, of which this is the first moment, and even after many years have passed she will still think: Yes, that was it, the beginning of my life.
title: Normal People
author: Sally Rooney

text: Not for the first time Marianne thinks cruelty does not only hurt the victim, but the perpetrator also, and maybe more deeply and more permanently. You learn nothing very profound about yourself simply by being bullied; but by bullying someone else you learn something you can never forget.
title: Normal People
author: Sally Rooney

text: It was culture as class performance, literature fetishised for its ability to take educated people on false emotional journeys, so that they might afterwards feel superior to the uneducated people whose emotional journeys they liked to read about.
title: Normal People
author: Sally Rooney

text: Marianne had the sense that her real life was happening somewhere very far away, happening without her, and she didn’t know if she would ever find out where it was and become part of it.
title: Normal People
author: Sally Rooney

text: It’s like something he assumed was just a painted backdrop all his life has revealed itself to be real: foreign cities are real, and famous artworks, and underground railway systems, and remnants of the Berlin Wall. That’s money, the substance that makes the world real. There’s something so corrupt and sexy about it.
title: Normal People
author: Sally Rooney

text: It suggests to Connell that the same imagination he uses as a reader is necessary to understand real people also, and to be intimate with them.
title: Normal People
author: Sally Rooney

text: If people appeared to behave pointlessly in grief, it was only because human life was pointless, and this was the truth that grief revealed.
title: Normal People
author: Sally Rooney

text: Their feelings were suppressed so carefully in everyday life, forced into smaller and smaller spaces, until seemingly minor events took on insane and frightening significance.
title: Normal People
author: Sally Rooney

text: Connell always gets what he wants, and then feels sorry for himself when what he wants doesn’t make him happy.
title: Normal People
author: Sally Rooney

text: He understands now that his classmates are not like him. It’s easy for them to have opinions, and to express them with confidence. They don’t worry about appearing ignorant or conceited. They are not stupid people, but they’re not so much smarter than him either. They just move through the world in a different way, and he’ll probably never really understand them, and he knows they will never understand him, or even try.
title: Normal People
author: Sally Rooney

text: The modern man thinks that everything ought to be done for the sake of something else, and never for its own sake.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Far too many of us have been lured into the cult of efficiency. We are driven, but we long ago lost sight of what we were driving toward. We judge our days based on how efficient they are, not how fulfilling.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: When work is what makes someone worthwhile and deserving, those who don’t work as much as possible are seen as undeserving and worthless.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: We’ll hold meetings and discuss trivial issues and send email and create agendas and add complexities until we need a full forty hours a week to do twenty-five hours’ worth of work.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: When time is money, idle hours are a waste of money. This is the philosophical underpinning of all our modern stress: that time is too valuable to waste. We don’t pass time, we spend it. It’s no wonder that we don’t really have pastimes anymore.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Time began to equal money. Employees worked with machines that put out a relatively stable number of products per hour. So the longer the machine was running, the more product a factory would produce and the more money the owner could make. More hours meant more money.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: We work best when we allow for flexibility in our habits. Instead of gritting your teeth and forcing your body and mind to work punishing hours and “lean in” until you reach your goals, the counterintuitive solution might be to walk away. Pushing harder isn’t helping us anymore.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Even today, despite the income gap being higher in the United States than in almost any other nation, many Americans believe they can rise to riches through honest labor, and that belief fuels a willingness to work too much, even when we’re not reaping the profits of our labor.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: People stopped bragging about their flat-screen TVs and started “complaining” about their packed schedules. Status was awarded not because you had an iPhone; everyone seemed to have an iPhone. Instead, people earned respect according to how little free time they had.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: We bring our work home with us now, answering emails at nine p.m. and picking up the phone when we’re out to dinner. That’s why I don’t have time for story tapes and dance classes anymore. But the leakage flows both ways. We also do a significant amount of nonwork activities while we’re at work.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Part of the problem is that we’re cutting out expressions of our basic humanity because they’re “inefficient”: boredom, long phone conversations, hobbies, neighborhood barbecues, membership in social clubs.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Essentially, we are working our way out of happiness and well-being. We’ve lost the balance between striving to improve and feeling gratitude for what we have. We’ve lost touch with the things that really enrich our lives and make us feel content. We’ve spent billions of dollars in the past decade or so finding replacements for what we as human beings already do well.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Keynes predicted that by 2030, people would work only fifteen hours a week and that would be enough to keep everyone fed, clothed, and housed. “For the first time since his creation,” Keynes wrote, “man will be faced with his real, his permanent problem—how to use his freedom from pressing economic cares, how to occupy the leisure, which science and compound interest will have won.”
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Employees were usually paid not by the task, as they had been for centuries before, but by the hour. I’ve tried to imagine what it was like for a worker at that time when they collected their first week’s wages after a lifetime of growing crops or tatting lace, but I find it difficult to conceive of a time when pay was unconnected to the hours invested.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Henry George wrote, a human is “the only animal whose desires increase as they are fed; the only animal that is never satisfied.”
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Many of us are exhausting ourselves this way, working very hard at things that accomplish very little of substance but feel necessary.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: John Swansburg, senior editor of the Atlantic, wrote about his father’s pursuit of the American Dream and the myth of the self-made man (and woman) and ultimately asks an important question: “Is it a healthy myth that inspires us to aim high? Or is it more like a mass delusion keeping us from confronting the fact that poor Americans tend to remain poor Americans, regardless of how hard they work?”
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Not thinking about your job is crucial, because every time you click that envelope icon, you are “polluting your time.”
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: When our minds are allowed to relax and rest, they return to what’s called the “default network.” This is the part of the brain that sorts through all the new information we’ve received recently and tries to put it into context with what we already know. The default network is integral to learning, insight, and imagination. If our minds never come to rest, there is never an opportunity to wander into new directions.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: First, many workers started using their extra income not to work less but to buy more.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: I realized it was not my circumstances that caused my stress but my habits.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: What is the cult of efficiency? It’s a group whose members believe fervently in the virtue of constant activity, in finding the most efficient way to accomplish just about anything and everything. They are busy all the time and they take it on faith that all their effort is saving time and making their lives better.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Since there is always something else to buy, there is never enough money for those of us in the middle class, and that means we are never working enough hours. The end result is that our off-hours start to feel stressful. Time is money, and we feel guilty when we waste it doing unproductive and unprofitable things.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Ferriss is just one of many people who hope to suck the marrow out of every moment of their day, to never waste time that could be spent moving toward a new achievement. A shortened workweek is something I endorse; torturing every minute in order to make every moment productive is not.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: So here is the complete list of solutions, all designed to break your addiction to efficiency without purpose and productivity with production. Increase time perception. Create your ideal schedule. Stop comparing at a distance. Work fewer hours. Schedule leisure. Schedule social time. Work in teams. Commit small, selfless acts. Focus on ends, not means.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: The glorification of consumerism creates a vicious cycle. We work longer and longer hours in order to buy products that we think will make our lives better, we stop enjoying them fairly quickly, the products themselves require time and maintenance that cut into our free time, this makes us unhappy, so we decide to relieve our feelings of sadness with a new product. Rinse and repeat.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Improvement is healthy, but not every moment of your day should be leveraged in an attempt to make you a better person.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: We work long hours in order to make more money, not realizing that once we’ve met our fundamental needs, it is leisure time that increases happiness, not necessarily extra cash.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Everything we think we know about work and efficiency and leisure is relatively recent and very possibly wrong.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Research shows that if you work without interruption for fifty to fifty-seven minutes, then take a short break, you’ll get much more done, and because you’re more likely to engage the executive part of your brain while using this schedule, your work may be more insightful and creative.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: The idea is not that everything should be slower, but that not everything needs to be fast.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Instead of investing our time in group activities like clubs or other hobby-focused groups, we are pouring our time into our jobs and into never-ending individual self-improvement schemes. But work is not a fundamental need, while community is.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: If your goal is less stress and more happiness, years of scientific research have proven that rather than trading your time for money, it’s best to trade your money for time.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: The key to well-being is shared humanity, even though we are pushing further and further toward separation.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: If you silence your phone, close your inbox, and really focus on getting a report done, research shows you’ll finish 40 percent faster, have fewer errors, and have plenty of time to take a short walk around the building and let your brain relax.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Sadly, two things occurred that prevented a drop in working hours: a rise in consumerism and a steep rise in income inequality.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Many of us become obsessed with means goals and completely lose sight of the more important end goal that should motivate all our efforts: living a good life.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: When you have fewer hours available to you, you automatically focus on the task at hand and ignore what’s irrelevant. The quality of your work goes up as the allotted hours go down, so you can often accomplish more in four hours than in five.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Many people who are now CEOs and millionaires have worked very hard, no question, but so have millions of people now living below the poverty line. Hard work is admirable, but statistics show it is not a magic potion that will transform your life.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: The sense that time was too valuable to be spent at a barbecue or baseball game started to make people feel anxious about what they did in their off-hours. Leisure began to feel stressful. In the back of their minds, people worried about the money they weren’t making.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: When asked, most parents say they just want their kids to be happy. And yet research reveals that what most parents actually want is high GPAs, because they think success in school will make their kids happy.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: What I learned is that if you don’t consciously choose a slower path, you will likely default to the pedal-to-the-metal speeds of modern life.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: People generally expect to hate talking with people in person and on the phone, but enjoy it when they’re forced to do it. That’s why it’s important that you force yourself to do it.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: If you’re thinking of early humans as primitive flower children who just did what they wanted all day, you may be surprised to discover that humans have a primal love for rules. We like structure and habits and routine. As the anthropologist Robin Fox says, “It’s the most basic feature of human nature. We’re the rule-making animal.”
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: In fact, the most productive of the group were those who put in between ten and twenty hours a week, or two to five hours a day.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Kids with helicopter parents are significantly more likely to suffer depression, and there’s a strong link between a highly structured childhood and a lack of executive-function capabilities. Children with helicopter parents often struggle to develop self-reliance and resilience. They have simply been too often protected from adversity.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: As Kate Raworth said in her 2018 TED Talk, “We have economies that need to grow, whether or not they make us thrive, and what we need, especially in the richest countries, are economies that make us thrive whether or not they grow.”
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Research has shown that having a rich social life makes you less likely to get cancer or suffer a heart attack. People who belong to a community live longer, experience less stress, and are more likely to say their lives are meaningful.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: In many ways, I think we’ve lost sight of the purpose of free time. We seem to immediately equate idleness with laziness, but those two things are very different. Leisure is not a synonym for inactive. Idleness offers an opportunity for play, something people rarely indulge in these days.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Leisure becomes stressful when you subconsciously believe you are wasting money by not being productive. However, if one of your end goals is to be happy, then pursuing a bigger income is not necessarily going to get you where you want to go. Allow yourself to consider other options.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: It’s a common mistake to evaluate ourselves and our lives by comparison instead of through objective measures. In other words, we strive to be as busy as or busier than our friends and colleagues instead of deciding what’s best for us.
title: Do Nothing: Break Away from Overworking, Overdoing and Underliving
author: Celeste Headlee

text: Just as Michael Pollan’s food ideology is summarized in three simple rules — “eat food, not too much, mostly plants” — the “company of one” model can be laid out in a similar fashion: “start small, define growth, and keep learning.”
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: The second characteristic of resilient people is a sense of purpose — being motivated by a sense of meaning rather than by just money.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: If you’re a company of one, your mind-set is to build your business around your life, not the other way around.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: A study done by the Startup Genome Project, which analyzed more than 3,200 high-growth tech startups, found that 74 percent of those businesses failed, not because of competition or bad business plans, but because they scaled up too quickly.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Instead of thinking, What product can I create? or What service can I offer, James believes that we should first think: What type of life do I want? and How do I want to spend my days? Then you can work backwards from there into a business model that allows you to create scalable systems to deliver your product to your audience.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Basically, you have to be good at your skill set before you can expect to achieve autonomy from using it.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: The last trait of resilient people in a company of one is the ability to adapt when things change — because they invariably do.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Next, let’s look at the four typical traits of all companies of one: resilience, autonomy, speed, and simplicity.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: The first trait that resilient people have is an acceptance of reality.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Graham notes that sudden and large investments tend to turn companies into “armies of employees who sit around having meetings.”
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Engaging work comprises four key components: clearly defined assignments, tasks you excel at, performance feedback, and work autonomy.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: The craftsperson mind-set keeps you focused on what you can offer the world; the passion mind-set focuses instead on what the world can offer you.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Don’t just ask consumers to pay attention to your business. Instead, start doing the kinds of unique and unusual things that attract attention in order to make your business distinct.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Sometimes “enough” or even less is all we need, since “more” too often equates to more stress, more problems, and more responsibilities in both life and business.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: When you focus on doing business and serving customers in better and better ways, your company of one can end up profiting more from the same amount of work because you can raise the prices until your demand flattens out to where you can handle it.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: In studying how trust is built between companies and consumers, Urban has found that there are three aspects of trust: confidence (“I believe what you say”), competence (“I believe you have the skills to do what you say”), and benevolence (“I believe you’re acting on my behalf”).
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Every minute you spend as a company of one in the ongoing development of a new product is a minute you aren’t seeing how well it solves a problem, and even worse, you aren’t making money from it or building toward your MVPr.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: A company of one is simply a business that questions growth.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: In many quickly growing companies, however, leaders feel that they are required to detach from human relationships and focus on using people as resources to achieve necessary growth by any means necessary. The problem is that a leader who stops feeling what is either motivating or demotivating within their team stops being able to lead.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: He learned from Seth Godin that selling to people who truly want to hear from you, because you’ve been sharing with them, is far more effective than interrupting strangers online who don’t even know you.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Passion and courage are almost impossible to control and can easily leave you feeling bad about yourself. It’s far easier to simply work at getting really good at something in demand, discovering how those skills can be applied to something else, and then testing your idea in a small way to see if it will pay.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: A Microsoft Research study found that attempting to focus on more than one priority at a time reduces productivity by as much as 40 percent, which is the cognitive equivalent of pulling an all-nighter.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Research done by Hewlett-Packard found that the IQs of employees who were interrupted by email, calls, or messaging were reduced by more than ten points — which is twice the impact of smoking marijuana.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Just as autonomy is achieved through mastery of skills and ownership of an ability to solve problems, so too is passion. Passion doesn’t precede mastery, but follows it.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Speed is not merely about frantically working faster. It’s about figuring out the best way to accomplish a task with new and efficient methods.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: To stand out and build an audience as a company of one, you have to out-teach and outshare the competition, not outscale them.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Staying small and not focusing entirely on growth keep your own integrity and personality at the heart of the business, making it much easier to run your business or team in a way that suits you and helps customers.

text: It’s assumed that hard work and smart thinking always result in business growth. But the opposite is often true: not all growth is beneficial, and some growth can actually reduce your resilience and your autonomy.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business

text: Companies of one do require leadership. text: Determining what is enough is different for everyone. Enough is the antithesis of growth. Enough is the true north of building a company of one, and the opposite of the current paradigm promoting entrepreneurship, growth-hacking, and a startup culture.

text: But bear this in mind: achieving control over a company of one requires more than just using the core skill you are hired for. title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business

text: Focusing on customer success is a mentality and a way of doing business for a company of one that encompasses all aspects of a business.

text: It’s much harder to compete with bigger companies on aspects like volume, low prices, or logistics. text: Personality — the authentic you that traditional business has taught you to suppress under the guise of “professionalism” — can be your biggest edge over the competition when you’re a company of one.

text: Being or becoming a company of one has a lot to do with resilience: the capacity and fortitude to recover quickly from difficulties — like a changing job market, or being fired.

text: A company of one finds its true north by working toward being better, not bigger, and the way to do that is to build long-term relationships with its audience and customers.

text: Envy is hard to manage, as it’s a socially unacceptable emotion, even though it’s something most people feel. Envy also takes the focus off your work, your business, and your customers. title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business

text: The word “intrapreneur” points to one example of a company of one within a larger organization. It describes corporate leaders who come up with their own goals and then execute them.

text: The gist is this: you can pursue any passion you want, but you shouldn’t feel entitled to make money off it. text: The truth is, much of business is a guess. That’s why it’s important to be able to bounce back and reenergize a team when failure strikes. Because it will.

text: “Success in business is no longer just about making money or moving up the corporate ladder. More and more, one of the biggest indicators of success is purpose.”

text: For a company of one to succeed, a strategy for simplifying isn’t just a desirable goal but an absolute requirement. Having too many products or services, too many layers of management, and/or too many rules and processes for completing tasks leads to atrophy. Simplicity has to be a mandate.
title: Company of One: Why Staying Small is the Next Big Thing for Business
author: Paul Jarvis

text: Companies of one need to become adept at “single-tasking” — doing one thing for an extended period of time without distraction. This capacity helps you focus on the right tasks, do them faster, and do them with less stress.

text: ONE OF THE legs that unrequited love stands on is the importance of the beloved—all the goals and dreams you’ve imbued him with. The goals and dreams don’t have to end, but their association with the beloved does.

text: One recent study shows that for people who have a high need to feel unique (a common characteristic of artists and innovators), social rejection causes them to score higher on tests of creativity. The outsider identity, which rejection reinforces, nurtures their ability to innovate.

text: “The seeker has a confirmation bias, looking for positive signs and discounting the negative ones,” Baumeister said. “If there’s ambivalence, it’s going to prolong the hope, because there are enough positives to seize on and overinterpret. The negatives you can brush aside.”
title: Unrequited: The Thinking Woman's Guide to Romantic Obsession

text: Even if we can’t stop our longing, we can consider using the urge to persevere in another way: to better understand ourselves. What does the beloved mean to us? What ideas, needs, or dreams have we cast upon him? Then we might begin to understand what it is we’re chasing.
title: Unrequited: The Thinking Woman's Guide to Romantic Obsession
author: Lisa A. Phillips

text: The pull of unrequited love can stem from a longing for transcendence, a need to experience great, impractical feeling. So for some of us, moving beyond obsession may entail finding something or someone with a similar ineffable power.
title: Unrequited: The Thinking Woman's Guide to Romantic Obsession
author: Lisa A. Phillips

text: “We’re always looking for that missing piece in ourselves,” said Jungian analyst Jacqueline Wright. “That ideal lover or person that we’re looking for holds a quality that we don’t recognize or express in ourselves.”
title: Unrequited: The Thinking Woman's Guide to Romantic Obsession
author: Lisa A. Phillips

text: Alice wasn’t really obsessed with Slater. She was obsessed with what was missing in her life. The real romantic possibility here—of a more fulfilled existence—was one that might very well be within reach.
title: Unrequited: The Thinking Woman's Guide to Romantic Obsession
author: Lisa A. Phillips

text: When we’re caught up in unsatisfied desire, we can write the story of our love and, for a time, control it. This is fundamentally a creative act, often full of pleasure at first. We can be self-centered in a way that’s impossible in mutual love. The situation is emotionally risky, because it’s all about yearning to be together—yet being together means facing reality, which will probably fall short of the self-centered fantasy.
title: Unrequited: The Thinking Woman's Guide to Romantic Obsession
author: Lisa A. Phillips

text: As for many unrequited lovers, her fixation on her beloveds is about a need inside her—a need to stay in touch with the dream of perfect unity with another.
title: Unrequited: The Thinking Woman's Guide to Romantic Obsession
author: Lisa A. Phillips

text: “Rejection can be useful if a person can reflect on it,” said Jacqueline Wright, an Atlanta-based Jungian analyst. “For example, what expectations did we have about the relationship? What unrealistic beliefs did we have about ourselves and the other person? This kind of reflection takes courage because of our tendency to take the easy way and blame a failure on the other person.”

title: Unrequited: The Thinking Woman's Guide to Romantic Obsession

text: And as Finn brushed his thumb across the back of my knuckles, it stirred something in me. It wasn’t a sexual feeling. I cannot stress enough how unsexy this all was; I was still blubbering—a stream of snot and tears was flowing freely down my face—and I had no desire whatsoever to be touched in that way. But I did want to be held. All I wanted, in fact, was to be held. And with that, as though reading my mind, Finn climbed around me, lay down behind me on the sofa, and collected me up in his arms. When he did that, I came undone. The tears fell faster. And my body shook even harder. I hadn’t realised how much I’d missed the feel of someone’s arms around me. I even said so out loud, but Finn said nothing in return. He just squeezed me tighter, his grip firm but delicate, like he was holding a glass statue instead of a girl.

text:
Just keep a log.

A mistake only counts as experience if you learn from it.

Record what you learned, and review it.

Otherwise, it was a waste.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text:
If you have feelings for someone, and you don’t let that person know, you’re lying with your silence.

Be direct.

It saves so much trouble and regret.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text:
And then there’s romantic love.

You never really regret falling in love.

Do it as much as possible.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text:
Projecting perfection onto someone is not love.

You say “I love you” but really mean “I love this”.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text: Beware of the feeling that someone completes you or will save you.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text: You must both be free and able to live without each other.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text: It’s illegal to sign contracts when drunk, so you shouldn’t sign a marriage contract when drunk on infatuation.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text:
Don’t wait for inspiration.

Inspiration will never make the first move.

She comes only when you’ve shown you don’t need her.

Do your work every day, no matter what.

Suspend all judgment when creating the first draft.

Just get to the end.

It’s better to create something bad than nothing at all.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text: Most of what you make will be fertilizer for the few that turn out great.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text: Your imitation of anything will be unrecognizably warped by your own twisted perspective.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text:
When you’ve finished a work, wait a while before you release it to the world.

By then, you’re on to something new.

The public comments won’t affect you, since they will be about your past work.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text: Stay in situations where you’re forced to show your work to others.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text:
Keep a counterweight job.

Something effortless that covers your bills.

Something you can do a few hours per day, but otherwise not think about.

It gives discipline and regularity to your life.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text:
Let the deadline of death drive you.

Create until your last breath.

Let your last spark of life go into your work.

Die empty, so death takes only a corpse.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text:
Don’t try to be more right.

Just be less wrong.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers

text:
Embrace what’s weird about you, and use it to create.

Never think you need to be normal or perfect.
title: How to Live
author: Derek Sivers
